paragraphs:
[1]
O'Reilly, J.
: Mr. Toni Dedaj applied for Canadian citizenship in 2007. He thought he had the exact minimum number of days of residency in Canada required by the
Citizenship Act
, R.S.C. 1985, c. C-29. The
Act
obliges applicants to live in Canada for three out of the four preceding years - 1,095 days. Mr. Dedaj thought he met that threshold, but a citizenship judge disagreed. She found that he was a couple of days short and dismissed his application. Mr. Dedaj appeals.

[2]
Mr. Dedaj argues that the judge erred in her finding that he did not meet the residency requirement for citizenship. He also suggests that she had a duty to go on to consider whether he had established and maintained his residence in Canada for the required duration, even if he was not actually physically present in Canada for all the 1,095 days.

[3]
In my view, while the citizenship judge was entitled to make the factual finding that Mr. Dedaj was not physically present for each of the required 1,095 days, she was also obliged to consider whether he had established and maintained his residence for that period of time. Accordingly, I must allow his appeal and order a reconsideration of his application for citizenship.
II. Analysis
(1) Factual Background

[4]
Mr. Dedaj left Albania in 1997 and moved to the United States where he met and married his wife. He arrived in Canada in 2002, made a successful refugee claim, and became a permanent resident in 2005. He claims to have been physically present in Canada from October 2, 2002 until August 30, 2007, the day he submitted his citizenship application. Because he was credited a half day for every day of physical presence in Canada prior to becoming a permanent resident, and a full day for every day thereafter, he achieved, in his view, exactly 1,095 days of physical presence in Canada as of August 30, 2007.
(2) The Citizenship Judge's Decision

[5]
The citizenship judge concluded that Mr. Dedaj had not met the residency requirement because he had stayed with his parents in the United States for a couple of nights during the relevant time frame. The judge was also concerned that, shortly after submitting his Canadian citizenship application, Mr. Dedaj had moved to the United States, had become a permanent resident there, had acquired a Michigan driver's licence, and obtained a U.S. social security number.
(3) Did the Citizenship Judge Err?

[6]
The citizenship judge deserves deference in respect of findings of fact. The Court will intervene only if those findings are unreasonable. In this case, it is unnecessary for me to determine whether the judge's findings were unreasonable because I am satisfied that the judge made an error of law.

[7]
Some years ago, this Court recognized that there was more than one valid approach to determining whether an applicant had met the residency requirement of the
Act
. The two principal approaches involve, on the one hand, a purely physical test and, on the other, a qualitative test of residency:
Canada (Minister of Citizenship and  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  at para. 11. In <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED> , I concluded, citing six main reasons, that where a citizenship judge finds that an applicant had not satisfied the physical test, he or she has an obligation to go on to apply the qualitative test. The latter involves an inquiry, based on a consideration of several factors, into whether the applicant had established and maintained a residence in Canada for the required period. The relevant factors appeared in
Koo, Re
, [1993] 1 F.C. 286; 59 F.T.R. 27 (T.D.).

[9]
In my view, the citizenship judge had an obligation to consider the qualitative test. While she did consider Mr. Dedaj's ties to the United States and commented on his having centralized his life there, she relied mainly on developments that post-dated his citizenship application. Further, she did not appear to consider the evidence supporting Mr. Dedaj's ties to Canada. Nor did she analyze the relevant factors from
Koo
, above.
III. Conclusion and Disposition

[10]
I will allow this appeal because the citizenship judge failed to consider whether Mr. Dedaj had met the residency requirement by having established and maintained his residency in Canada for the required period, even if he was not physically present in Canada for all of the 1,095 days. I will return the matter to another citizenship judge to reassess Mr. Dedaj's application.
JUDGMENT

[11]
THIS COURT'S JUDGMENT IS that
1. The appeal is allowed and a reconsideration of this application for citizenship, by another citizenship judge, is ordered.
Appeal allowed.
Editor: Angela E. McKay/pdk
[End of document]

legal_issues: Whether a factual finding by an administrative tribunal regarding residency requirements should be overturned for error of law.
Whether an applicant's residency for citizenship purposes is determined solely by physical presence, or if a qualitative assessment of establishing and maintaining residence is also required.
Whether an administrative tribunal has a duty to consider alternative legal tests when an applicant fails to meet a strict, initial threshold requirement.
The appropriate scope of evidence considered when assessing an applicant's residency, specifically regarding the relevance of post-application conduct.
factual_background: An individual applied for Canadian citizenship in 2007.
The applicant believed they met the residency requirement of 1,095 days under the Citizenship Act.
A citizenship judge denied the application, finding the applicant short of the required residency days.
The applicant emigrated from Albania to the United States in 1997.
The applicant married a US resident.
The applicant arrived in Canada in 2002 and made a refugee claim.
The applicant became a permanent resident of Canada in 2005.
The applicant claimed continuous physical presence in Canada from October 2, 2002, to August 30, 2007.
The applicant briefly stayed with parents in the United States during the relevant time period.
Following the citizenship application, the applicant moved to the United States.
The applicant obtained US permanent resident status, a Michigan driver's license, and a US social security number after submitting the Canadian citizenship application.

Applicants: Met the residency requirement of 1,095 days based on physical presence, including credited days as a permanent resident.
The citizenship judge erred by not considering whether he had established and maintained his residence in Canada for the required period, even if not physically present for all 1,095 days.
Evidence supports his ties to Canada, which the judge did not adequately consider.
The judge relied too heavily on post-application events (move to the US, US driver's license, social security number) and did not analyze relevant factors from *Koo*.
Respondents: Did not meet the residency requirement because he stayed with his parents in the United States for a couple of nights during the relevant time frame.

His move to the United States shortly after applying for citizenship, becoming a US permanent resident, and obtaining a Michigan driver's license and US social security number indicated he had centralized his life there.

court_analysis: The court found the citizenship judge erred in law by failing to consider whether Mr. Dedaj had established and maintained his residence in Canada, even if he didn't meet the strict 1,095-day physical presence requirement.

The court acknowledged prior Federal Court jurisprudence establishing two approaches to determining residency: a purely physical test and a qualitative test. It affirmed the obligation of citizenship judges to apply the qualitative test when the physical presence test isn't met.

The court relied on its previous decision and other Federal Court cases (Koo, and subsequent cases cited) to support the existence of the qualitative test, which examines factors demonstrating an applicant's ties to Canada.
The court determined deference to the citizenship judge’s factual findings was not necessary because the error lay in the *application of the law*, not the assessment of facts.
The court found the judge’s focus on post-application activities and lack of consideration for evidence of Mr. Dedaj’s ties to Canada demonstrated a failure to properly apply the qualitative test.

The court ordered a reconsideration of the application by a different citizenship judge, specifically directing that the judge assess whether Mr. Dedaj had established and maintained his residence in Canada despite potentially falling short of the exact physical presence requirement.
final_outcome: A reconsideration of the application for citizenship, by another citizenship judge, is ordered.
